summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy document (P6360.01) titled 'Pharmacy Services,' dated January 15, 2005. It outlines comprehensive procedures for pharmacy operations within federal prisons, including staffing, standards of operation, controlled substance management, and patient safety protocols. It is a standard operating procedure and contains no direct references to the Epstein case, individuals, or specific events. This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Program Statement (P6360.01) detailing comprehensive policies and procedures for pharmacy services and controlled substance management within federal correctional institutions. It outlines strict protocols for storage, inventory, dispensing, administration, and error reporting of medications, with a significant focus on DEA-controlled substances. This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy statement (P6360.01) titled 'Medication Administration: Inmate Pharmacy Services' dated January 15, 2005. It outlines comprehensive procedures for medication management, error reporting, controlled substance handling (including methadone), and patient counseling within federal correctional institutions. It is a standard operating procedure and does not contain specific case information related to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Chief Pharmacist

persons.name: Warden

persons.name: HSA
persons.context: The health services supervisor who designates the chair of the Controlled Substances Inventory Team and receives memos regarding theft or loss of drugs.

persons.name: Medical Director

persons.name: Chief of Psychology

persons.name: Special Agent-in-Charge

keyFacts: This document is a standard Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy manual for pharmacy services, dated January 15, 2005.
It details procedures for managing controlled substances, including DEA registration, security, inventory, and record-keeping.
The policy establishes roles such as the Chief Pharmacist and Health Services Administrator (HSA) with specific responsibilities for pharmacy operations.
It references standard correctional and pharmaceutical guidelines but contains no information specific to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or his incarceration.
This is a detailed Bureau of Prisons policy (P6360.01) governing all aspects of pharmacy operations and controlled substance management in federal prisons, dated January 15, 2005.

The policy mandates extremely strict protocols for DEA-controlled substances, including secure storage, biennial and quarterly inventories, and specific reporting procedures for theft or loss directly to the DEA.
Medication administration to inmates must be directly observed, with inmates required to show an empty mouth to prevent 'cheeking' (hiding medication).
The document outlines a formal, blame-free Medication Error Program focused on system improvement, categorizing errors per American Society of Health Systems Pharmacists guidelines.
Institutions without pharmacist services for more than three days must contact the BOP Medical Director for guidance, highlighting the critical role of pharmacy oversight.
This is a standard Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy document (P6360.01) on medication administration and pharmacy services for inmates, dated January 15, 2005.
The document details procedures for medication error reporting, severity ratings (Level 0-6), and reviews involving the Chief Pharmacist and Quality Improvement Program (QIP) coordinator.
It contains specific regulations for the use, storage, and licensing of methadone within BOP institutions for detoxification, treatment of pregnant inmates, and pain management.
The policy outlines strict controls for needles and syringes, including shift inventories and secure storage separate from controlled substances.
The document is signed by Harley G. Lappin, who was the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons at the time.
